dt.t: {wi}They{/wi} aren't as popular as {wi}they{/wi} once were.

dt: used to refer to people in a general way or to a group of people who are not specified

dt.t: {wi}They{/wi} say the trial could go on for weeks.

dt: used with a singular indefinite pronoun antecedent

dt.t: No one has to go if {wi}they{/wi} don't want to.

dt: used with a singular antecedent to refer to an unknown or unspecified person

dt.t: An employee with a grievance can file a complaint if {wi}they{/wi} need to.
The person who answered the phone said {wi}they{/wi} didn't know where she was.

dt: used to refer to a single person whose gender is intentionally not revealed

dt.t: A student was found with a knife and a BB gun in their backpack Monday, district spokeswoman Renee Murphy confirmed. The student, whose name has not been released, will be disciplined according to district policies, Murphy said. {wi}They{/wi} also face charges from outside law enforcement, she said.

dt: used to refer to a single person whose {d_link|gender identity|gender identity} is nonbinary {dx_def}see {dxt|nonbinary||c}{/dx_def}

dt.t: I knew certain things about … the person I was interviewing.… {wi}They{/wi} had adopted their gender-neutral name a few years ago, when {wi}they{/wi} began to consciously identify as nonbinary—that is, neither male nor female. {wi}They{/wi} were in their late 20s, working as an event planner, applying to graduate school.

usages.pl: Can {parahw}they{/parahw} be used as an indefinite subject?
pt: {it}They{/it} used as an indefinite subject (sense 2) is sometimes objected to on the grounds that it does not have an antecedent. Not every pronoun requires an antecedent, however. The indefinite {it}they{/it} is used in all varieties of contexts and is standard.

usages.pl: Can {parahw}they{/parahw}, {parahw}their{/parahw}, {parahw}them{/parahw}, and {parahw}themselves{/parahw} be used as singular pronouns?
pt: {it}They, their, them, themselves:{/it} English lacks a common-gender third person singular pronoun that can be used to refer to indefinite pronouns (such as {it}everyone, anyone, someone{/it}). Writers and speakers have supplied this lack by using the plural pronouns.

pt.t: and every one to rest {it}themselves{/it} betake
I would have everybody marry if {it}they{/it} can do it properly
it is too hideous for anyone in {it}their{/it} senses to buy

pt: The plural pronouns have also been put to use as pronouns of indefinite number to refer to singular nouns that stand for many persons.

pt.t: 'tis meet that some more audience than a mother, since nature makes {it}them{/it} partial, should o'erhear the speech
no man goes to battle to be killed.—But {it}they{/it} do get killed

pt: The use of {it}they, their, them{/it}, and {it}themselves{/it} as pronouns of indefinite gender and indefinite number is well established in speech and writing, even in literary and formal contexts. In recent years, these pronouns have also been adopted by individuals whose gender identity is nonbinary, as illustrated in sense 3d above.

et: Middle English, from Old Norse {it}their{/it}, masculine plural demonstrative & personal pronoun; akin to Old English {it}thæt{/it} that
shortdef: those ones : those people, animals, or things
—used to refer to people in a general way or to a group of people who are not specified
—used with a singular indefinite pronoun antecedent

dt: {bc}an international organization that promotes the spiritual, intellectual, social, and physical welfare originally of young men

shortdef: an international organization that promotes the spiritual, intellectual, social, and physical welfare originally of young women —usually used with the —sometimes shortened informally to the Y

dt: used to describe someone or something as having a characteristic to the highest degree

dt.t: Their daughter is {phrase}as clever as they come{/phrase}.
The movie was {phrase}as boring as they come{/phrase}.

shortdef: —used to describe someone or something as having a characteristic to the highest degree

dt: usually used in negative statements to mean that someone should not depend on something hoped for until he or she knows for certain that it will happen

dt.t: Don't {it}count your chickens (before they hatch){/it}—you don't know yet if she will accept your offer.

shortdef: —usually used in negative statements to mean that someone should not depend on something hoped for until he or she knows for certain that it will happen

dt: {bc}to allow events to happen without trying to change them
usually used to suggest that one is willing to accept a result, whatever it may be

dt.t: I will run the best campaign I can, then {it}let the chips fall where they may{/it}.

shortdef: to allow events to happen without trying to change them —usually used to suggest that one is willing to accept a result, whatever it may be

dt: used to introduce a common saying or a statement that expresses a common belief

dt.t: Keep trying, and you'll figure it out. {it}You know what they say{/it}: if at first you don't succeed, try, try again.

shortdef: —used to introduce a common saying or a statement that expresses a common belief

dt: {bc}to seize especially with teeth or jaws so as to enter, grip, or wound
{bc}to wound, pierce, or sting especially with a fang or a {d_link|proboscis|proboscis}
{bc}to cut or pierce with or as if with an edged weapon
{bc}to cause sharp pain or stinging discomfort to
{bc}to bite or have the habit of biting something

dt.t: The anchor {wi}bites{/wi} into the ocean floor.

dt: {bc}to respond so as to be caught (as by a trick)
{bc}to accept a suggestion or an offer

dt.t: offered them a deal but they wouldn't {wi}bite{/wi}

dt: {bc}to take or maintain a firm hold
{bc}to be objectionable or extremely bad in quality {bc}{sx|stink||}, {sx|suck||}
{bc}to imitate or copy (someone or something) especially without permission

dt.t: There are lots of rappers {wi}biting{/wi} his style—but there's only one James Brown!

dros.drp: bite off more than one can chew

dt: {bc}to undertake more than one can handle
{bc}to hold back (as from a reluctance to offend) a remark one would like to make
{bc}to enter with resignation upon a difficult or distressing course of action

dros.drp: bite the hand that feeds one

et: Middle English {it}biten,{/it} going back to Old English {it}bītan,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*bītan-{/it} (whence Old Saxon {it}bītan{/it} "to bite, cut into," Old High German {it}bīzan,{/it} Old Norse {it}bíta,{/it} Gothic {it}beitan{/it}), going back to Indo-European {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}ei̯d-{/it} "split," whence also Latin {it}findere{/it} "to split, cleave, divide" (from a derivative {it}*b{sup}h{/sup}i-n-d-{/it}), Sanskrit {it}abhet{/it} "has split," {it}bhinátti{/it} "(s/he) splits" and perhaps Greek {it}pheídomai, pheídesthai{/it} "to spare, save, refrain from"
shortdef: to seize especially with teeth or jaws so as to enter, grip, or wound
to wound, pierce, or sting especially with a fang or a proboscis
to cut or pierce with or as if with an edged weapon

dt.t: the {wi}where{/wi} and the how of the accident

dt: {bc}a place of central interest or activity
{bc}something (such as a topic or field of interest) of primary concern or importance
{bc}to the fullest extent of one's value or ability {dx}see also {dxt|for what it's worth|for what it's worth|}{/dx}

et: Middle English, "having monetary value, valuable, having status, deserving, highborn, efficacious, strong," going back to Old English {it}weorþ, wyrþ, worþ{/it} "having monetary value, valuable," going back to Germanic {it}*werþa-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}werth{/it} "of value," Old Saxon {it}werth{/it} "of value, worthy, dear," Old High German {it}werd, wert{/it} "of value, valuable," Old Icelandic {it}verðr{/it} "of value, worthy," Gothic {it}wairþs{/it} "deserving"), of uncertain origin

The Middle English adjective continues in part Old English {it}wierðe, wyrðe{/it} "worthy, deserving," a ja-stem adjective from the same base. Welsh {it}gwerth{/it} "worth, value, price" (whence {it}gwerthu{/it} "to sell"), along with Middle Breton {it}guerz,{/it} is perhaps an early loan from Old English.
